metadata.titleEn: HiWATER: Dataset of ground truth measurements synchronizing with TerraSAR-X satellite overpassing in the Daman Superstation on June 26, 2012
metadata.description:
On June 26, 2012, the satellite transit ground synchronous observation was carried out in the TerraSAR-X sample near the super station in the dense observation area of Daman. TerraSAR-X satellite carries X-band synthetic aperture radar (SAR). The daily transit image is HH / VV polarized, with a nominal resolution of 3 m, an incidence angle of 22-24 ° and a transit time of 19:03 (Beijing time), which mainly covers the ecological and hydrological experimental area of the middle reaches artificial oasis. The local synchronous data set can provide the basic ground data set for the development and verification of active microwave remote sensing soil moisture retrieval algorithm.            
Quadrat and sampling strategy:            
Six natural blocks are selected in the southeast of the super station, with an area of about 100 m × 100 m. One plot in the northwest corner of the sample plot is watermelon field, others are corn. The basis of sample selection is: (1) considering different vegetation types, i.e. watermelon and corn; (2) considering the visible light pixel, the sample size of 100m square can guarantee at least 4 30 M-pixel is located in the sample; (3) the location of the sample is near the super station, with convenient transportation. The observation of the super station is in the north, and there is a water net node on both sides of the East and the west, which makes it possible to integrate these observations in the future; (4) in addition, there are some obvious points around the sample, which can ensure that the geometric correction of the SAR image is more accurate in the future.            
Considering the resolution of the image, 21 splines (distributed from east to West) are collected at 5m intervals. Each line has 21 points (north-south direction) at 5m intervals. Three hydroprobe data acquisition systems (HDAS, reference 2) are used to measure at the same time. The sampling interval is controlled by the scale and moving splines on the measuring line to make up for the lack of using hand-held GPS.            
Measurement content:            
About 440 points on the quadrat were obtained, and each point was observed twice, i.e. two times in each sampling point, one time inside the film (marked as a in the data record) and one time outside the film (marked as B in the data record); although the watermelon land was also covered with film, considering that it was not laid horizontally, only the soil moisture at the non covered position was measured (marked as B in the two data records). As the HDAS system uses pogo portable soil sensor, the soil temperature, soil moisture (volume moisture content), loss tangent, soil conductivity, real part and imaginary part of soil complex dielectric are observed. Because the vegetation in this area has been sampled and observed once every five days, no special vegetation synchronous sampling has been carried out on that day.            
Data:            
The data format of this data set is vector file, the spatial location is the location of each sampling point (WGS84 + UTM 47N), and the measurement information of soil moisture is recorded in the attribute file.

Feature Specification.Question: What features are considered when selecting a sampling area for soil moisture measurement using remote sensing techniques?
Feature Specification.Answer: diversity of vegetation types, size of the area, proximity to observation stations, presence of distinct landmarks

Quantification.Question: How many sampling points are included in a dataset related to TerraSAR-X ground synchronous observations?

Definition.Question: What is the purpose of a ground synchronized observation dataset in the context of synthetic aperture radar (SAR) data collection?
Definition.Answer: A ground synchronized observation dataset serves as a foundational ground-truth reference that aids in the development and validation of soil moisture retrieval algorithms using active microwave remote sensing. It involves taking precise, simultaneous ground measurements to match satellite overpass times, ensuring data consistency and accuracy for further analysis.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the choice of specific sampling strategies and locations in ecological hydrological remote sensing experiments?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The choice of sampling strategies and locations in ecological hydrological remote sensing experiments is influenced by various factors, including the diversity of vegetation types, the size and visibility of sample plots relative to the resolution of satellite imagery, proximity to observational stations for logistical convenience, and the presence of identifiable landmarks for accurate geometric correction of SAR imagery. Additionally, considerations for integrating existing observational networks and ensuring robust data for soil moisture algorithm development and validation are also pivotal.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of using ground-based synchronized observations with TerraSAR-X satellite data for soil moisture retrieval in artificial oasis eco-hydrological regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of ground-based synchronized observations with TerraSAR-X satellite data can lead to the development and validation of soil moisture retrieval algorithms using active microwave remote sensing. By collecting detailed ground truth data, researchers can enhance the accuracy of soil moisture models, particularly in artificial oasis eco-hydrological regions. This approach also facilitates the integration of different observational networks (e.g., WATERNET nodes) and improves the geometric correction accuracy of SAR images, aiding in more precise ecological and hydrological assessments.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary goals of conducting satellite overpass ground synchronized observations using TerraSAR-X in ecological and hydrological research?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary goals include developing and validating active microwave remote sensing algorithms for soil moisture retrieval, leveraging the high-resolution TerraSAR-X imagery and ground-based measurements to improve the accuracy and utility of remote sensing data in ecological and hydrological studies.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedural steps involved in conducting synchronized ground observations with TerraSAR-X satellite imagery for soil moisture retrieval in a designated ecological and hydrological test area?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedure involves selecting sampling plots based on diverse vegetation types such as watermelon and corn, ensuring plot size aligns with visible light pixel coverage. Plots are chosen near a superstation for accessibility and integration with existing observation networks. Ground observations are synchronized with the TerraSAR-X satellite overpass, using a 5-meter interval to collect 21 east-west sample lines, each with 21 points spaced 5 meters apart north-south. Three Hydraprobe Data Acquisition Systems are used for simultaneous measurements. Soil moisture and temperature are collected using portable soil sensors, with two observations per point for covered corn fields and non-covered points in watermelon fields. Data is stored in vector format with spatial positions and soil moisture information recorded in attribute files.
